commentBody: Loved it!  Very clever theme.
Very unique theme- loved it. For some reason I was convinced 4 -Across was CardiB and that took me ages to resolve.
Nice puzzle. Got any Thursdays though?
I pulled 4 Across out of my, um, hat. Yeah, hat!
I figured it out from crosses but had no idea what acunit is.. Air conditioning unit I guess??
Nice puzzle. Liked the theme, but pretty quick for a Thursday.
Did anyone else incorrectly enter "RED" for 39A? (This was purely unconscious; I don't think of myself as that closed minded.)

Happy 23, Adam Wagner.

Wow.
An uncommon fast Thursday solve Out West. Although enjoyable, wondered about staying power for ALDI, JARULE and TIVO. Luckily, they're tucked in quite nicely with enough grist to get them through the archive mill in 2030 and beyond.

Quick chuckle over the ACUNIT dripping on the urban sidewalk. Out here, we just run around in circles and spray our bare feet with the watering hose. If the house is warm, it'll keep cutworms and visitors away.

I didn't get the theme until looking at the article. I think the clue for LIL should have had a theme-related hint.

The fill was pretty solid, if not too easy for a Thursday and with average cluing.

6/10.

I was slowed down by starting with acidic instead of ACETIC and not knowing either rappers from over 20 years ago or sports team nicknames. 
But the last to fall was because of my first guess of "pal" for 1A, with a mental note that MAC was just as likely and that I'd have to check on that later. Then, not that much later, I was stuck trying to guess the luxury brand/Swedish currency cross while blithely not noticing that I had left the "p", giving me "pAC" for 1A. Doh! Talk about a face-palm moment!

Thought this was fun overall. 

62 across “Parisian boulevard” the answer is boulevard. Rue means street.
Great theme!

Thought I would get a start on tomorrow's puzzle, and I was so captivated I ended up doing the whole thing. Very clever! I didn't know JA RULE at all, so that was the last to fall. I also really enjoyed Deb's column...love her solving method tips! Hee hee. I've definitely employed "staring woefully;" maybe I will add in "sighing plaintively" in the future to help even more!

Enjoyable puzzle, which I solved without the faintest clue why the theme answers related to clues, getting them only by  seeing the word patterns once I had a few crosses.  And I completed it faster than it would take me to hitchhike from Saginaw. Did a forehead slap when I read Wordplay and had the theme explained to me.  Quite clever.

I had detag instead of UNTAG and only got ACUNIT by the crosses, and even then it took me a minute to actually “get” it.
Solved. Would have never gotten the theme without reading the blog.
The Constructor Notes were terrific!
Never got the theme, but it was easy enough to fill out the whole puzzle without it.

I adore “America” by Simon and Garfunkel, so I loved seeing that clue and instantly and excitedly sang the lyric out to my wife who was less enthused lol. 

This was clued a bit simply for a Thursday imo. I didn’t really get the theme clues until after I’d completed it. I don’t necessarily hold that against the puzzle/creator — it happen — but it does make me enjoy the puzzle a bit less.
I like the theme, but 4A/4D was a Natick for me, as was 14A/3D.

OOPSIE was a nice little extra diminutive in the puzzle - you use it when OOPS is just too big for your situation.

More words should have diminutives!
Like, say:

STUDLING
TRUTHETTE
UTURNITO
Wrong language for 40 down… Greek, not Latin

Cute themelet. So cute I could eat it's little face! Finished in almost half my average Thursday time despite having to get a lot of answers from crosses. Figuring out the theme fairly early also helped with some of the fill. For those who regret hitting send... If you use Gmail, you can undo your send, and you can specify in your settings how long you want it to wait for you to change your mind. (I've needed to use this more often than I'd like to admit.) https://support.google.com/mail/answer/2819488 How did I remember JA RULE? It's funny the info stored deep in my brain that only makes it's way to the surface while solving crosswords.
right off the bat i typed “biggiE” for 4A and struggled for a while in the north cause of it. lol

Enjoyable puzzle, and when I finally got the theme, it amused me.  Probably the favorite was [Rockette?]

The one that I'm not so sure about is 5D.  It is true that vinegar is a solution of water and acetic acid, but the "acid" part of "acetic" is very important.  

What's the term the wordsmiths here came up with for this.  "Too Close Syndrome"?

Anyone else bothered by ACETIC?

Done in by ALDI, again. Not the first time that store has gotten me. They just don’t exist in my neck of the woods. I had STUb for [ear piece]. Was thinking “corn”. 

I find making a comment here can help a lot with remembering for my next RUN IN. 

(ALDI, ALDI, ALDI)

Fun puzzle - clever theme. Perhaps a bit easy for. Thursday but you won’t hear complain about that.
Welp, the people who complain about calling Odin the Norse God of war should be happy to see TYR today. And I wouldn't have known it, if not for those complaints, so thanks.
A fun puzzle once I figured out the diminutive angle, but Deb’s column and the constructor's notes made my day. Thanks for the much needed humor!

Quick and fun!

I sure do love Gmail's "Undo" button. Fun tip: did you know you can customize thr number of seconds it gives you to change your mind? I give myself a generous 15 seconds to have second thoughts. I use it far too much.

For those familiar with the long-standing beef between them, do you know how many times JA RULE has appeared in the crossword compared to 50 Cent? I guess it would more difficult to input the latter given the numeric part of his name.
Fun Thursday.
I finished but had to look here to understand. Too cute by half.
Eritrea is based on GREEK, not Latin.

What is a ling?  Fingerling sandwich is just a finger-shaped sandwich.  Any other examples?     Sorry, theme is weak.  I read the column and shook my head.  But I got my gold star using the crosses and Google.
Can anyone explain why “speakers” is plural in 28 across?
Nice Wednesday puzzle.

The theme... I got it in the end. I didn't find it particularly fun, and if it was witty at all then only witty-ish in a cringey dad-joke sort of way.

The fill was mostly easy, but the area directly north defeated me - after staring at it for a long time I looked up the rapper and the football player. It didn't help that I had "wee" rather than LIL.

ACUNIT confused me after crosses revealed it. I couldn't parse it for a while. Then I saw it was in fact an AC UNIT. Them dropping onto the pavement happens where you live? We've had AC UNITs in Poland for decades now, and I've never heard of a single case of one falling down. The threat of criminal liability for manslaughter rather strongly discourages AC installers from doing a bad job.

Almost set a PB, but never once got the theme. Even after reading and understanding it, I couldn’t help but think “oh, is that it…” boring.

Decent puzzle, poor theme.

About the article: attics themselves are vented to remove hot air, moisture, etc. and they also contain vents from house to roof to get rid of nasties such as gas or stove smoke. That is why they are great for ventilation. Other than tying this clue to the clever AC Unit entry, I don't see the connection.

That was a cute LIL theme.
REAR stumped me, though. I've been riding horses ever since I could walk, but I've never once had one REAR on me when spooked. They do, however, love to bolt in that situation.
 
But it's funny, between horses and scuba diving, I seem to require my hobbies to be dangerous and very expensive.

As a native Italian speaker, 40 down did confuse me. The closest I could come up with in Latin for Red Sea was something like "Marrosso" and thought it could have been Morocco for the answer (which wouldn't have made any sense given its geographical position). I believe Eritrea must be the Greek name for it?

Anyone else have fun with this up until the recently news-making OOPSIE? Another joy undercut by a reminder of unserious people doing serious harm… Sorry for the digression, apart from that a delightful puzzle, even if the Greeks named Eritrea before the “Latins”.

A bit of a slog, actually, a few complete unknowns, I won't list them all! But 4A/4D was impossible even after I revealed a J. 

ERA - HOORAY - I remembered! Thank you Steve. 

The word 'sub' even after all the crosswords I've done here, still doesn't relate to a sandwich, and FINGER SANDWICH sounded like something from a horror film to me. Didn't know PINKY RING either. 

But I got lots and lots through crossers, without knowing what the words meant, which felt quite odd.

Because of 12D I've been listening to that masterpiece of song writing.  Paul Simon is an indisputable genius.  I mention below that there are no rhymes in "America"--it's purely prose lyrics.

And it made me nostalgic for America, the country.  I would like to go out looking for it.  I once loved it very deeply, but I haven't seen it in a while.

I'm just afraid I won't find it, and maybe I should leave the memory in the past, undisturbed.
I managed to solve it, but I didn’t really enjoy the theme. I also wasn’t a fan of the use of proper names—as if they were universally known.
Fwiw, I liked the theme. It was clever and fun. Good puzzle!
Solved it in nine minutes, but took me a good few minutes looking through it after solving to understand the theme. Cute
Maybe not Thursday tough, but I thought the theme was great.  Even after figuring it out, each one elicited a laugh.  [Rockette?] for GRAIN OF SAND, and [Shoveling?] for GENTLE NUDGE were favorites.

I was mentally composing a complaint about the injustice of crossing the name of a French holding company with a subdivision of a currency I knew nothing about when I realized that, somehow, I knew the answer.

I had to look up the rapper, and even after I got the music ACUNIT had me staring at it baffled me for a while (yes, I did eventually figure it out). Running two words together always throws my pattern recognition for a loop. You'd think I'd watch for it, but no...it trips me up like Lucy holding the football, every time.
“I don’t love that new hair color, but NEW DO HUE, honey.”

I zipped through this one (it’s my fifth fastest Thursday), filling in the theme answers entirely from the letter patterns and sometimes not looking at the clues. 

Then I stared at the completed grid for much longer trying to suss out the theme. [Bandidto] and [Rockette] gave me a hint that the theme clues were cutesy diminutives, but I couldn’t see past the shovel in [Shoveling] to make any sense of that. I eventually put the puzzle aside (turning to a crunchy Rich Norris Saturday from 2008) and eventually went to sleep. 

I woke up around 4 and decided to give the diminutives another shot. This time, I saw how they all worked. 

Someone suggested that LIL might have been clued more obviously as a revealer. I think the puzzle would have benefited from some sort of a clear revealer, but maybe I was just extra dense last night. 

Oh, well. I’ve enjoyed Adam Wagner’s puzzles before, and I expect I’ll enjoy them again. This one just didn’t do it for me.

Great LIL puzzle!
I specially liked the reference to MAC- my dad used to call people that, like at the tollbooth - "Thanks Mac!" Haven't seen or heard that expression for a long time...

Typical tough Thursday for me and had to work out most of the theme answers from the crosses. And... will confess that even now there are a couple of those that I'm not entirely grasping. No big deal. And my appropriate puzzle find today is another whose theme I don't entirely get. A Monday from June 10, 1996 by S. Spadaccini. Three 'theme' answers (I guess) in that one - all straightforwardly clued. ANGELHAIRPASTA ARTICHOKEHEARTS FINGERSANDWICH Puzzled. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/10/1996&g=59&d=A I'm outta here. ...

Ooh, I really dug this. 
I mean…wordplay!

Rockette was the revealer for me.

The previous themers felt *kinda*
sensible, but got them from either crosses,
or just “seeing” the answer and hoping I was right.

Once it clicked, I loved it.
Sublet = FINGER SANDWICHES?

Hooray!
Happy Thursday all!
The Friday of Fridays!
This solved pretty quickly after I sussed out the theme, but nevertheless it was a fantastic construction! Very clever theme, with plenty of fun non-theme fill, and no junky fill to be found
Why should Laos get all the elephants? I'm afraid another Executive Order is needed.

This puzzle was spark-ling!







Et tu, emu.
You know it's a complicated theme when you solve it but still have to come here to learn what those longer clues even mean.

I stopped after I had three theme answers filled in, determined to solve the theme.  I love when a theme is stumping me, when I start thinking, “I’m going to figure you out and I’m not filling in any more until I do.”  My brain lives for this.

Today I finally saw those diminutive suffixes in the clues, cracked the theme, and felt good all over from that as well as from experiencing Adam’s wit.  

Funny moment was uncovering FINGERSAND and confidently turning it into FINGERS AND TOES.  

I appreciate Adam's skill in coming up with these theme answers, which are filled with spark, as three of them are NYT answer debuts, and the other two are once-befores.  Four of them – all except VENDING MACHINE – truly shine.

I also smiled at the cross of OOPSIE and a backward OOF.

Just a splendid Thursday, with plenty of rub to happify my brain, topped by that sweet theme-crack.  Thank you greatly for this, Adam.

I stared and stared and stared. I even came close when I parsed 57A as [Rock-ette], but missed the others. It was only when I saw the headline to Deb's column, at the bottom of the screen, that it clicked.

I really liked the clue to 10A, although a more accurate version would be [Meas. which becomes a third of its size when changed from upper- to lowercase], since, Who has time for all those extra letters? Hey, I got orders to fill! It's T. and t., respectively, as in the final line of my recipe for lentil soup--

Season with 1 t. NaCl and 1 T. CH3COOH sol.

***

In our drives between Detroit and our place Up North, the Zilwaukee Bridge, which spans the Saginaw River, lies about halfway. It effectively marks the boundary between Southern and Northern (Lower) Michigan. Radio reception changes there. It's useful as a touchstone for calls home, as in "I'm just crossing the big bridge that Jim* hates--I'll see you in about an hour and a half." It's nice to see Saginaw getting some love.

*a reference to my Brother-in-Law, who suffers from gephyrophobia (one of many).

***   ***

It's funny, spell-check didn't like NaCl (or Zilwaukee, or gephyrophobia), but had no problems with CH3COOH.
Finally caught on with FINGERSANDWICH (after correcting my GETme).  Loved the theme.  Thanks.
Beautiful puzzle, and the story of its genesis is terrific: the reasoning for not including GROVELING makes good sense!

Neat
Sweet
Petite

with a bonus themer in 9D.

And wasn't Steve just yesterday commenting that a 3-letter baseball stat could be ERA or RBI?

OOPSIE, gotta go. Time for my daily marathonette on the beach.

RE: constructor comments. 
Groveling is a great word and fitting for the times.

Amazing puzzle. I got the theme with GRAINOFSAND, which allowed me to work out the centre with PINKYRING.

One nit. A Parisian boulevard is a boulevard. Not really a rue.

I solved up (south to north) on this puzzle, so I hit on GRAINOFSAND and FINGERSANDWICHES together  and convinced myself the theme had something to do with "s-a-n-d" and diminutives. I didn't cling too hard to this theory and had to give it up quickly, but I felt a little sad to let it go. I don't even know what that extra layer would have signified, but I think Sunday's puzzle may have made me greedy for more complexity and wheels within wheels. That said, this was a pretty fun solve.
Adorable!

A GENTLENUDGE is a shove-ling. Like a duck-ling is a little duck.

A VENDINGMACHINE is a mart-ini. Like bambini are little children. (OK, we seem to have a singular/plural issue here, since it's not VENDINGMACHINES.)

A PINKYRING is a band-ito. Like a gatito is a little cat or kitten.

A FINGERSANDWICH is a sub-let. Like a starlet is a little star, e.g., an up-and-coming actress.

A GRAINOFSAND is a rock-ette. Like a statuette is a small statue.

OK, the theme and themers generally make sense. And the fill in general is quite solid. But somehow I didn't really enjoy this one. Probably because I was hoping for Thursday trickery, and this is simply a nice Wednesday puzzle.

Solved it easily enough, but no feeling of HOORAY!

wasps are not a common apple orchard pest!

mites, worms, and nonsensical clues are, though
A littke bit of pure Thursday joy.

I had a time in the upper middle because I had “detag” and “get the nudge” for the longest time and couldn’t let go of either. And no way o was going to get ACUNIT or JARULE without a lot of help. Finally pulled out RUNIN which opened it up. Also MOET and ORE were Naticks for me, although I could guess MOËT from the remaining letters. Rest was pretty smooth sailing, and clever tight theme.

Love it!

I don't know if the puzzle was constructed this way on purpose, but the theme only resolved for me from the last two theme answers.  I would have never gotten it from the top three.

Often, the "revealer" of a tricksy themed puzzle is in the SE corner of the puzzle and I after getting through puzzles like this I always resolve to start my next puzzle (at least on Thursday or Sunday) from down there to help myself out.  

But I haven't yet remembered to do it.

I found something a *little jarring* about that 4A / 4D section, and can’t help but wonder if the constructor considered but abandoned any themed -ule words…  cuz I sure did.

I like a theme where you have to squint to see it.
Fun!
Today was close to my best time for a Thursday. Felt like a Friday to me.

Grumble. 

Although I did chuckle at MANUALS. Our cars all have standard transmissions. When we attmpt to use valet parking we often encounter a sign that states "No Stick Shifts" allowing us to park ourselves in the nearby valet lot.

Clues were too tricky for this solver.

Thank you Adam for my humbling experience.

This was my new personal best for a Thursday! And less than a third of my average - with no help or look ups! This felt more like a Tuesday to me and I'm not complaining. A fun puzzle and I enjoyed figuring out the cute "little" theme!
Re: 1 Down, isn’t the company Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessy (LVMH) - not Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton (MHLV)?
Too much like a cryptic puzzle for my solving enjoyment

Yeppers, the clue for 40D is rather troublesome--not right, but not wrong either, just troublesome. It's like asking [Country whose name comes from an Italian phrase for "lion mountains] (=SIERRA LEONE), which it does, even though both elements come from Latin ("serra" ["saw," as in "sawtooth mountains" and "leo/leonis"). Also, is "Mare Eritrea," a phrase, or simply a name?

What did the Proto-Indo-Europeans call the Red Sea?

Rolling down my window): Say Mac! Yeah you in the Jaguar, you're Ja Rule, right?

I thought so. VIP written all over you. Wow that's some stud in your ear, and that pinky ring, that's definitely outa some vending machine! If that went down the drain (oopsie!) you could send me down after it! And I'd do it! And the moral would be, a la Aesop: Even a refugee from Eritrea can end up on top!

You don't get it? That's a little acetic of you, Ja. I'm not from Eritrea, silly! I'm an Aztec from Laos, near Saginaw. Anyhooray, where are you going in that Jagitini of yours?

To the REM concert at the NACL-NSFW Arena ["The Nack"], wow! Me, I'm going to see Lil Foo at Acu-Nit East, her latest rap album went double platinum gold, "TKOs Era Tour," have you heard it? I've played my copy so often it skips, right in the middle of "U Mad Ewe" when she's singing

      Gentle nudge in my ryr, 
       run in u turn 
       neckrub Moet
       shed a Tyr

Well, Mr. Rule, please precede, I mean proceed. Don't stay out past your bedtime! It's good to see you (and it's good to be seen). 

(Later at a diner): Waiter! There's a grain of sand in my finger sandwich! 

What's that mean? "The eel's on Dr. House." --?

Oh! The meal's on the house? Thanks!

And thanks also for this knotty challenging grid, leaving us in need of a mental neckrub. Much enjoyed it. Cervezas on Dr. House!

I was completely dooked by 15A. I stared at it for a while and wondered what the heck was an ACUNIT. 🤣

The theme was not as tricky as Thursday usually is, but I still enjoyed it. I like silly puns, lol
Anyone else balk at ACUNIT?
The theme was clever and sweet. Good cluing, and just right for this Thursday. Thanks!
I done did this puzz
The first one I solved was GRAINOFSAND, and from there I was quite a happy camper. Got stuck on litTLENUDGE… perhaps I needed one of my own. :)
Decent puzzle. Have absolutely no clue what the theme was but the rest was good enough I was able to solve without it

Color me appreciative for a challenging wordplay theme that almost had me not missing a Thursday rebus...almost. And if "Shoveling" replaced "Groveling" that must have been a mighty re-design.

+5 points to me for getting the rapper's name with just the first letter. (Jodeci is R&B.)

Then, deduct 5 points for not knowing that one of my favorite Yes tracks was a cover of a Simon & Garfunkle song. Because Gen X.

Got stuck in the upper middle.  Had ACIDIC and JAYZEE for the longest time, and was trying to make GIVEAWEENUDGE work.  

Eventually figured it out!
Didn't pick up the theme until the end but thought it was clever
Big trouble with the northwest corner today.

Cute theme! I fought the impulse to solve the grid but not take the extra step of figuring out the theme (and this was before I'd actually fully solved the grid!). Taking that extra moment gave me extra satisfaction when the "a-ha" hit -- and helped me with the last of my fill. Eventually. (I see I'm not alone in having the middle top as the last to fall! For me, blame that on acidic vs. ACETIC.)

However, I have to say there was some pretty shoddy editing on this grid! The outright error at 10A that got changed around 7-8am Eastern -- literally from one pass to the next for me -- from [Meas. that becomes a third of its size if its third letter is removed] to the correct [second] letter. Then the "troublesome" 40D (as @Bill in Detroit calls it, and many other comments have pointed out). And while some have rationalized [Paris boulevard] solving to RUE, I'm firmly in the camp that a Paris boulevard... is a boulevard! 

For the record, 10A held me up a fraction; I got 40D immediately from having ER and not considering etymology; I plunked in RUE without hesitation but with a big eye roll. If it hadn't been for 10A, I probably would have just sighed and moved on... PINKY swear! 

Thanks, Adam! Fun puzzle and great back story!

I was about to ask if anyone else thought 35A had to be Spanish, but decided to look up its origin. So, I was today years old when I learned that “bandito” is Italian for bandit and NOT Spanish. I’m going to go out on a limb and say that was the fault of the Frito Bandito earworm. Enjoy! https://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=i+am+a+frito+bandito+commercial&view=detail&mid=29F9D1E098A5B694E65D29F9D1E098A5B694E65D&mcid=E2BC8E797EE646ADA66B24A930531E18&FORM=VIRE&PC=APPL
Although I got the theme early on, it still took a bit to parse the answers. But I managed to finish in about 2/3 of my average time for a Thursday. Very enjoyable 16 minutes.
I finished the puzzle.  If I hadn't read the Gameplay afterwards, I would have never have known how those clues were related. Oh well.  :)
Had to have Google autocorrect a search for ACUNIT to recognize it. Just not something that would ever come to mind living in western Washington.
If the constructor had actually put MICROFOREST in the puzzle, I would have had to call the language copse.
Ok, I don’t actually get 2D. What is with car service and ARRIVAL?
Had GRAINOFSALT instead of SAND for too long. Didn't help I had no idea the Hebrew My Lord clue

I got stuck right at the end because I had ACIDIC instead of ACETIC crossing with LITTLE NUDGE instead of GENTAL NUDGE.

Tricky!

43 across is why turning on the "undo send" option in Gmail (mine is set for 5 seconds) has saved me lots of embarrassment over the years.  Maybe we can have that option too when we hit "submit" here?

Strands!
Plz, no spoilers until after "view all replies"

Strands #403
“What's the buzz?”
🔵🔵🟡🔵
🔵🔵🔵

Bzzzz
For 4A/D I had to run the alphabet with the keyboard. Mentally wouldn't have worked. Neither of the answers rings a bell with me.
In 1D, the order of the brands is wrong. It is LV_H.
Did this and it was fine but have definitely had more fun on other Thursdays.
I clearly need to brush up on rap.
I’m not sure a VENDINGMACHINE is really a small mart. But hey, gotta stretch to fit the theme sometimes.

TIL that EMINEM and JARULE have the same number of letters.

(As soon as i got to 4D I figured out that it wasn't EMINEM, but then it took me a while.)

I guess I'm stressed out in general because I hated this one. Dripping in urban areas was unsolvable and like many I had Eminem ( and Eli crossing) which was problematic. Oopsie was a bit much. I gave up because I was t having fun with the arcane theme

Took me longer than usual today 14:29.  Not that I have ever listened to his music, (much less be able to identify it if I did), but I knew it had to be JaRule when Eminem didn't make sense.  And I groaned when I finally read 15 across correctly.
An excellent Thursday puzzle IMO. A head-scratcher of a theme, but enough support in the rest of the puzzle's clueing to keep it accessible.
I got it, but i really didn't get it.

Vicious natick in the top left, MOET / MAC / ORE. Didn't know any of them and just guessed.

Overall I did enjoy this one, and the theme clues are great, but a lot of the surrounding clues really tripped me up. ERITREA coming from Red Sea was hard for someone who knows the Latin words for read and sea but not a lot of proper nouns. And, looking it up, I like the clue even less. It comes most recently from Italian (mare eritreo) via the Latin "erythraeus" which is clearly a loanword from Greek and also not a phrase. Yes, the name itself emerged via Latin more recently than Greek, but the full phrase (mare erythreum) is not the full name for the country. I know this is pedantic but if I can't give into my worst pedantic impulses in the NYT crossword comments section, then where can I?

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot. Interesting clues, and answers all around.Yes, I did not understand the connection between the clues and the answers, but I was able to fill everything in without knowing that. Once I read the column and went back to look at the words, it all made sense. Thank you for a lovely Thursday puzzle!

The theme eluded me for quite a while, and I kind of groaned when I got it - seemed kind of a stretch - but as I reviewed the theme answers it sort of grew on me. It's a degree more subtle than the typical theme, so I admire that. The cluing throughout sort of annoyed me for some reason, and I needed four lookups to complete the NW and N sections, although I did guess JARULE somehow, one of those pop culture names I recognize but have no idea who it is. One lookup doesn't bother me, two leave me disappointed. Four takes all the fun away. Oh well.
Great puzzle, and the constructor note made me appreciate it all the more
Yet again, it's entirely possible to solve the puzzle without ever "getting" the theme.
A gentle nudge being just a “SHOVE-ling”  was cool to me.

Mr. Wagner,

Who are you FOOLing?!  I have a few ACUNITos to pick with you.

Do you have a VENNdetta?  
Going against the socialistico GRAINOFSANDinistas?

DRHOUSE sez "More bloodletting than an AZTEC ACETIC, or when
MAC the knife had a FINGERSANDWICH.

This was sooo TYRing!  I'm ready for a NECKRUB and
a Relic GRISTling IPA CERVEZA, and become
ERITREAvably lost in REM.

Who am I FOOling?  Maybe I'm RUEing your USE of TKOS. 
BIG ME. I'm THE PRETENDER.
THESE DAYS, I WALK AMONG the BEST OF YOU. You're MY HERO.

EVERLONG.

i do wish you would return to the more intellectual puzzles of yesteryear and not use so many names or rappers and jargon.  for example, instead of -------king, it might have been Franklin or face on bill.  etc.

When the 19th- and 20th-century scholars unpacked ancient scripts - hieroglyphs, runes, dead alphabets - they were bridging gaps of
lost knowledge.

Things once familiar, known, taken for granted, yet allowed to have passed out of use, after too many generations of people who didn’t care about what happened before they were born, or even before living memory…

-ling is certainly on the list of things doomed to die. Only Tolkien fans have half a chance of saving it from complete obliteration.

The -l- is indeed diminutive/endearing and the -ing is ergative. Mein Liebling = “my darling” in the same way that my darling = my dear-l-ing (my dear-l-ing = dear to me + diminutive + ergative “I actively endear you, sweetie”). That -l- diminutive is seen in Yiddish “shtetl” (little town), in Pennsylvania German “Hundli” (puppy/little dog), in German “Hansel” (Johnny / little Johannes).
When English has utterly forgotten that it was born of Germanic stock, the language will indeed have been lost.

-ling primarily connotes TNG : the next generation. The ancient Greeks used -ides to mean “the offspring/children/daughters/sons of…”
And English used “-ling” the exact same way.

Pleiades
Thenglings

@Steph Fun fact: boulevard comes from the German bulwark. When a German architect was hired to rework Paris (1700s I think), the city was growing and they had to remove the old city walls. The architect decided that, instead of placing buildings where the walls were, he would make new wide roads. He referred to the former walls as bulwarks, and the French adapted the word to boulevards to refer to the new roads. In essence, it became the opposite of what it was.

@Wayne C They didn’t “have to” remove the city walls. They decided to. Paris was a very medieval city up to the Napoleonic period when they nearly completely demolished it. One of the most thorough intentional urban razing projects.

@Wayne C This process happened allover Europe. Some cities replaced their walls with boulevards, others with parks. For example, the old town of the historic Polish capital Kraków is surrounded by the wonderful Planty park - laid out in the 19th century when the medieval and early modern fortifications were largely demolished (However, the medieval barbican remains intact, an extremely rare relic of military architecture). By then the city had been fortified by the Austrians (who ruled there then) using mid-19th century technology - a ring of brick forts with earthworks surrounded it. Interesting fact: these mid-19th century forts quickly became obsolete, too. In most places in Europe such fortifications were demolished within decades of their construction, to be replaced by an even more modern iteration, utilizing reinforced concrete rather than brick. In Kraków, however, they remain - one of few such examples on the continent. More on Wikipedia: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w_Barbican https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planty_Park_(Krak%C3%B3w) https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w_Fortress

@Steph

I would argue that boulevards, avenues, drives, lanes, etc. are all varieties of the generic “street” regardless whether the signage specifically indicates “street”. That’s my take anyway.

@Andrzej I remember the park surrounding the old town. I've stayed in Krakow for two Christmases and a summer holiday, once on Florianska close to the Rynek Glowny, and remember women singing Christmas carols near the gate at the other end. As an exercise in "where was I?", I've looked at pictures I've taken of the trams that are often routed along the boulevard, then used Google maps to find the exact location, which often brings back a flood of memories about everything else that was going on when I snapped the pictures.

@Wayne C Georges-Eugène Haussman was born in Paris (of parents of German descent), and the massive urban renewal he undertook was in the 19th century (mid 1800's) working for Napoleon III. But yes, the gist of your comment -- the widening of roads to boulevards -- is true. :) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges-Eug%C3%A8ne_Haussmann https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haussmann%27s_renovation_of_Paris

A "natick" is when the square could literally be any letter of the alphabet, such as a name starting with an initial -- which was the initial use of the term, when the town of NATICK crossed with the artist NC WYETH. 

14A/3D cannot be a "natick" because here the square at the cross has to be a vowel: 5 possibilities, not 26.

I have to say, as another New Yorker, I'm surprised you didn't know the Spanish word for beer! 

(I'd also venture to say 4A/D isn't a true "natick" either, since a little logic dictates what the Jacksonville team would be, especially if you had _AG... That said, this was 100% the most difficult section of the puzzle for me!)

@Francis. ACETIC is the adjective derived from the Latin “acetum” meaning vinegar, so it literally means [vinegary]

@Francis Vinegar isn’t just an acetic acid solution, though that’s what you often get sold in the store (and the source can be petroleum). It derives from plant material, traditionally wine in Europe, and so has other things in it that provide flavor.
@Francis - quite the contrary; the primary meaning of acetic is vinegary, from the Latin acetum = vinegar. Acetic acid is named for vinegar, not the other way around.

@Striker

Apparently there are 108 ALDI stores in California. Who knew??

@Striker 

I know a German chain store in an American grid will always be ALDI, and it was today, too. We have those in Europe, obviously, but Lidl is my mind's first choice for 4 letter German supermarket - Lidl is probably the most ubiquitous store chain in Europe, and no wonder: their value for money is awesome. Also, every Lidl store has a similar layout, so shopping is as fast and easy for me in Warsaw, Palermo or Munich. However, despite the uniformity of layout, Lidl stocks local and regional products and produce. Cool stuff.

@Andrzej

We have Aldis here in Aus, but no Lidls (at least AFAIK). But I still tried Lidl first for some reason!

@Striker - They are all over (12,000 stores worldwide). There is another four letter German discount chain, Lidl, also worldwide. So I waited for crossings on that one.

Aldi gets its name from ALbrecht DIskont (the founder’s name + discount).
Lidl gets its name circuitously: the founder was named Schwarz; when they opened the discount stores his son didn’t want to use the name Schwarz Markt because it means black-market, so he wanted to use the name of his father’s business partner, Lidl. Lidl’s family wouldn’t sell rights to the name so they found somebody with that name and paid him a small sum for the name anyway.

IKEA has the initials of its founder, his farmstead, and his hometown behind its name. Another four letter chain, but Swedish this time.

@Striker

Lidl tries to immitate local grocers, but its stores are quite large (not quite supermarket-size, usually, but much larger than any regular store), and they are owned by a corporate behemoth.

The Polish gorcery market is extremely competitive, but over the past two decades or so chain stores have dominated it - Żabka, Biedronka, Lidl, Aldi, Kaufland, Carrefour, etc., etc. Small, family owned shops just can't compete with those economies of scale, which is sad.

That being said, farmers' markets are a thing - we call them bazarek (diminutive of bazar, and that word does not need a translation). Most of the stalls on a bazarek are run by farmers and artisanals manufactures of jams, cured meats, etc. The bazarek is quite the Polish institution. Unlike a typical Western European street market, a bazarek is plebeian, with low prices for high quality, non-industrial produce. Of course people of all walks of life shop there. On the weekends, when farmers' markets always get most traffic, a Warsaw bazarek will be surrounded by atrociously parked BMWs, Audis, Porsche SUVs, ancients Volkswagen diesels, rusting fiats - and at the stalls the new-rich in Gucci will be queueing alongside teachers, workers and pensioners. Quite the phenomenon.

Honest question.  What happened to the voters who put the 2015 regime into power in the first place?  

Did they change their minds?  Have they been narrowly in the minority since?

Because I think about 50 to 60 million votes are utterly unchangeable.  That's most of what is needed to win the country and all that's in it.

@Francis

Not much changed with those people. The populists of the PiS party (the irony of the name in English is brilliant) can always count on about 30% of the vote. However, it was about everybody else coming together to vote the populist oligarchy out. The turnout in the 2023 elections was record-breaking: over 73% (in the past it had usually been ca. 50%), with some districts achieving over 90% (I'm proud to live in an area of Warsaw with some of the country's highest turnout, and lowest support for the populists). With how the Polish proportional electoral system works, the 30% support for populists can translate to either 30% or even as much as over 50% of the seats in parliament. A unified front of the opposition, and the support it could rely on, meant a defeat for the populists. They still got their 30% of the vote, but they lost their majority in parliament.

@Roberta 
Thanks. I've never heard of 'hero' for a sandwich either! I wonder how that came about.

@Jane Wheelaghan

“Sub” for submarine sandwich. Named, I assume, for its shape. Also called by various other regional names, such as hoagie (Philadelphia) and grinder (Boston). “Hero” (plural: heros) is the local name in New York.  

But thanks to Subway sandwich shops, “sub” is now known (if not typically used) everywhere. 

It’s a long roll, typically filled with cold sliced meats, tuna, or hot items such as meatballs or chicken Parmesan, and in the case of the cold cuts, with lettuce, tomatoes, various other vegetables on top, at your discretion, cheese if you want it, and condiments such as mayonnaise, oil and vinegar, etc. Vegetarians and vegans can get veggies only. You can buy a whole roll or an half.  Everyone is happy.

Two depressing thoughts:

1.  Job requirements for valet parking jobs do not include the ability to park cars with manual transmissions.  I guess the language has evolved to the point where "standard" no longer applies.

2.  Employers are no longer willing to train employees whether it's driving skills or computer languages and applications.

@dk
Is anyone else picturing Richard Gere in "Pretty Woman," trying to drive the MANUAL Lotus Esprit? I'll bet the valets in Beverly Hills are trained to handle that.

@dk 

We once waited an inordinately long time at the BMW dealership for them to bring our car up after it had been serviced. 

It turned out that none of their porters knew how to drive a manual. That surprised me, but maybe it shouldn’t have. We’d had to go from Austin to Houston to test-drive the model we wanted with a stick. 

Now we have a Subaru with an automatic transmission. It’s just hard to find a stick shift anymore.

@Amy Interestingly, the initials are the inverse of the spelled-out name. "LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE, commonly known as LVMH, is a French multinational holding company and conglomerate that specializes in luxury goods and has its headquarters in Paris, France. The company was formed in 1987 through the merger of fashion house Louis Vuitton (founded in 1854) with Moët Hennessy, which had been established by the 1971 merger between the champagne producer Moët & Chandon (founded in 1743) and the cognac producer Hennessy (founded in 1765)." See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LVMH
